Explaination: A unique identifier given to each study, is the same across datasheets.
The title of the study the data was extracted from.
The authors of the study the data was extracted from.
The title of the source the study was published in (eg. journal name).
The year was the study published.
the main domesticated grazer species studied in the publication.
What was the domestication status of the grazer species identified (domesticatedd, wild, or both).
what kind of comparison was studied (gradient, grazed, ungrazed, etc.).
How many years had passed before the study was performed since the landscape had been grazed.
The duration of the study performed in years.
Latitude of the site or centroid if multiple sites in decimal degrees.  Multiple sites are separated by a semi-colon.
Longitude of the site or centroid if multiple sites in decimal degrees.  Multiple sites are separated by a semi-colon.
the elevation of the site, or average elevation across multiple sites, in meters. Multiple sites are separated by a semi-colon.
The  country were the study was performed
the number of sites that were surveyed within the study
The survey method for collecting the responding animals
was there indeginous grazers present in the study area (yes or no)
were there domesticated grazers present in the study area (yes or no)
The status of the plant community as either: 1) P = planted/seeded or 2) SA = allowed to self assemble
The type of ecosystem where the experiment was conducted (e.g. forest, desert, alpine). Multiple locations are separated by a semi-colon
Whether the larger study area (excluding exclosures) was open or fenced
If the study area tilled or not tilled
a list of all the herbivores present in the study area mentioned in the paper separated by a semi-colon (not including species lists, such as from appendices)
If fertilizer used within the study sites (yes or no)
If fire (for example, perscribed burns) a significant part of the study
Was the study area publicly or privately owned
The year that the study initiated
The year that the study ended
a unique identifier given to each study, is the same across datasheets
Whether the responding specimen was a vertebrate or invertebrate

The taxonomic rank within kingdom for the target species or group of species within the study. When species name was provided, the taxonomy was queried from the global biodiversity information facility (GBIF.org)

The taxonomic rank within phylum for the target species or group of species within the study. When species name was provided, the taxonomy was queried from the global biodiversity information facility (GBIF.org)

The taxonomic rank within class for the target species or group of species within the study. When species name was provided, the taxonomy was queried from the global biodiversity information facility (GBIF.org)

The taxonomic rank within order for the target species or group of species within the study. When species name was provided, the taxonomy was queried from the global biodiversity information facility (GBIF.org)

The taxonomic rank within family for the target species or group of species within the study. When species name was provided, the taxonomy was queried from the global biodiversity information facility (GBIF.org)
Taxonomic genus of measured specimen
Species of measured specimen
The response variable that measured the study species (e.g. abundance, diversity, behavioural, fitness)
ID given within the paper for a specific site studied
what year was the site studied
number of replicates of the site treatments in the study
Determination of the grazing contrast was based on a gradient of intensity (e.g. stocking rate) or a contrast between ordinal groups such as grazed vs. ungrazed.
Grazing categories or comparisons for ordinal contrasts. Only applicable for the ordinal/binary compare
how many years had the landscape been grazed when the study was performed
what estimate of grazing was used in the study
for the specified site, what was the value of the grazing estimate determined
The statistic used to summarize the response of the speciman (e.g. mean, median, standard error).  If listed as "count" this represents the plot-level measurement of individuals
The measured value of the responding specimen
